user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_response_element_n_:
```c
struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *
MHD_get_response_element_n_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                             enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                             const char *key,
                             size_t key_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  mhd_assert (NULL != key);
  mhd_assert (0 != key[0]);
  mhd_assert (0 != key_len);

  for (pos = response->first_header;
       NULL != pos;
       pos = pos->next)
  {
    if ((pos->header_size == key_len) &&
        (kind == pos->kind) &&
        (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header, key, pos->header_size)))
      return pos;
  }
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: for (pos = response->first_header;\n       NULL != pos;\n       pos = pos->next)
explanation: The for-statement header and the function call inside the loop body are flagged because Rule 14.2 constrains the three clauses of the for loop and also requires consideration of the behaviour of any functions called from the loop body. The remaining lines are not suspicious for Rule 14.2: the mhd_assert checks occur before the loop and have no effect on the loop clauses; the individual comparisons (pos->header_size == key_len) and (kind == pos->kind) are pure reads of the loop counter and parameters and introduce no persistent side effects; the return pos; simply exits the function. There are no other for loops or constructs in this function that would need investigation under Rule 14.2.
